dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARCELLINE ARDOIN, a soulful black nurse is bopping down. the street to the same music on her Walkman. A toy poodle pulls her by the leash into the shadow of an archway. She turns at the SQUEAL OF BRAKES nearby.

dialogues.speaker: THE STREET 5
dialogues.text: A chromeless late-model Ford pulls up to the curb. Two Figures pull a THIRD FIGURE out of the back seat and stagger drunkenly into the Piazza D'Italia, leaving the ear doors open. MARCELLINE tugs the leash, dragging the poodle down the street past the Ford. She glances inside the car, pauses, noticing something we can't see, glances back toward the Figures in the piazza. The poodle WHIMPERS, -tries to jump into the car. Marcelline pulls the dog away, boogie-ing on to the music in her head, then disappearing into the shadows of some fake-Roman statuary that borders the piazza. Two Figures run out of the piazza, jump into the Ford, PEEL OUT. Marcelline turns the corner, past the office of the "New Orleans Italian-American Society". The poodle is tugging at the leash. Marcelline stoops, unhooks the leash, and the little peodle makes a bee-line for the fountain in the center of the piazza..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The poodle scampers up to the fountain, starts to YELP as it sees THE. BODY OF FREDDIE ANGELO floating in the water T Marcelline: SCREAMS, looks down the street after the disappearing Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marceline picks up the phone, dials 911.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE ON TELEPHONE
dialogues.text: (filtered) Police Department. Where is your emergency? Marcelline stares at the phone.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE ON TELEPHONE
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello! Police Department! She Rance un

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freddie's body lies sprawled, half-in-half-out ofthe. illuminated, Italy-shaped pool. The square is deserted. IN A SERIES OF CUTS, we SEE two SQUAD CARS arrive, 10 ONLOOKERS. gather, an AMBULANCE pull up, a FORENSIC UNIT, PHOTOGRAPHERS taking pictures of the body and the scene, hunting for clues, COPS setting up barricades, etc., etc. Finally, a beautifully waxed Chrysler LeBaron convertible pulls in through the fake-Roman arch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LeBaron, radio blasting out WWOZ backbeat, turns into the square.

dialogues.speaker: PATROLMAN
dialogues.text: Closed, pal. (then) Oh, sorry,. Lieutenant. LIEUTENANT REMY McSWAIN gets out of the convertible and walks toward the crime scene. Remy is a marked contrast to the other detectives on the scene with their beer bellies and sloppy suits; Remy is trim, very fit, carefully barbered and -- even at. this hour -- very expensively dressed. He's a dude.

dialogues.speaker: KELLOM
dialogues.text: Remy! Over here. A uniformed Police Captain, JACK KELLOM, waves Remy over to. the body. He's big, beefy, jolly; sports a big red nose. He has a doting, paternal tone with Remy.

dialogues.speaker: KELLOM
dialogues.text: Where you coming from? Don't you ever sleep? ’ REMY (grins) Only when the music stops, cher. (walking over to the body) What. do we have here?

dialogues.speaker: KELLOM
dialogues.text: You. make him?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Sure. Freddie Angelo, a wise guy... Works for "The Cannon". Handles Mexican imports for the Family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Remy, you've a good eye for the cops. To me they all look alike. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective McCabe leaves off examining the masonry of the Piazza with a flashlight and comes over to the Captain. She's a short-haired, tom-boyish redhead, 20's. In the man's world of the Homicide Bureau she holds her own with the boys. She greets Remy with a punch on the arm. McCABE Can't find any bullet hits, spent shells, nothing like that. Very little blood. We figure they smoked him someplace else, then brought his body here. He had twelve hundred cash in his money clip and a Piaget Watch, all untouched.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (impressed) Piaget? McCABE Here's: the wallet, they just got through lifting the prints.

dialogues.speaker: REMY .
dialogues.text: The driver's license is missing. . * McCABE I figure the killer took it for proof of the hit. Standard wise- guy procedure, right, Remy? REMY. Standard if they were gonna wrap him in a concrete overcoat and drop him in Lake Pontchartrain. But. here's Freddie in all his glory, right in the middle of the Piazza D'iItalia. What does that tell us? McCabe shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (looking around) . Given the surroundings, I'd say it ( ) was a message to the esteemed president of the Italian-American Association.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCABE Vinnie "The Cannon" Di Moti Remy pinches McCabe's cheek.

dialogues.speaker: REMY -
dialogues.text: Bring Mr. Di Moti in for questioning first thing tomorrow. . McCABE (gulps) Suppose he won't come!

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Arrest him as a material witness. You'll find him at the barber shop. He's. always there around ten. Captain Kellom puts his arm on Remy's shoulder and pulls him away from the others.

dialogues.speaker: KELLOM
dialogues.text: Forget the Cannon: your father never got him. I never got him, and your're never gonna get. him.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Gotta keep trying cher. It's like a family tradition.

dialogues.speaker: ON MARCELLINE ARDION.
dialogues.text: the black nurse who was walking her poodle in the Piazza d'Italia last night. She is talking urgently across a desk to

dialogues.speaker: ANNE OSBORNE
dialogues.text: It's her office. She's a lawyer, 27. There's a great looking girl in there, somewhere, but she goes out of her way to hide it--she's all business. She listens earnestly as Marcelline finishes her story, then rises and ushers the nurse and her LAWYER out of the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as it swings around the corner, past a barbed-wired- enclosed tent city of prisoners, then by the huge ‘prison itself, and into the garage of Police Headquarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON A CARTOON CUT-OUT hanging on a wall: a grinning vulture. As the shot WIDENS, we see the vulture's perched on a blow-up of the brass, crescent-shaped shield of the New Orleans Police Department. As camera WIDENS FURTHER we see that the whole thing is hanging over the doorway of the Homicide Squad. Remy enters through the open doorway, dressed in a very well-cut business suit. There are about a dozen desks occupied by DETECTIVES. In the back are two glassed-in offices, one small, one large. Anne sits waiting in the small office - Remy's. In the larger office Captain Kellom is bawling out ED DODGE and ANDRE DE SOTO. They are both about Remy’s age -came out of the Police Academy together, but neither has fared as well as Remy. De Soto has eaten. himself into a mountain. Dedge is thin, always needs a shave, and wears. a cheap toupee. As soon as’ Kellom spots Remy, he bursts out into the squad room, leaving Dodge and De Soto standing there, hangdog.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: What'd they do now?

dialogues.speaker: KELLOM
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Impounded a boat...spent half their shift down at the goddam Police Deck! What am I gonna do with these guys?

dialogues.speaker: . REMY
dialogues.text: Why don't we shoot em?

dialogues.speaker: . KELLOM
dialogues.text: Nah, they're fun to have around for Mardi Gras. 14 is

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge. and De Soto brighten up, saunter out into the squad room. Remy notices Anne sitting by his desk.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Who's that in my office?

dialogues.speaker: KELLOM
dialogues.text: That's Anne Osborne. She's an Assistant D.A.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I've heard about her. She's with the strike force investigating corruption.

dialogues.speaker: KELLOM
dialogues.text: Yeah, but she's here about. the Angelo murder. We got written orders to co-operate. Make nice.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (grins) She's in. good hands, cher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy enters, all smiles, sticks out his hand to Anne Osborne, perches on the corner of his desk, hovering over her, turning on the charm. . REMY. Anne? Hi, Remy McSwain

dialogues.speaker: ANNE-
dialogues.text: How do you do, Lieutenant. I've...

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Remy.. Remy gives her a big smile

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Lieutenant. I'm here to find out what: progress you've made on the Angelo. murder.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (big smile) What's your hurry? The guy’'s not even stiff yet.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (sardonic) : He is dead, though, isn't he? :

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: } Last time I saw him.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Is. that it? No clues, leads?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (grins) , Not: so far. Look, I've seen dozens of these wise-guy jobs. We usually find out why the hit went down; sometimes we find. out who did it; we even make an arrest once in a while, but we never have: enough to take to court. Anne who has been writing furiously on her legal pad, suddenly breaks the point of her pencil. As Remy : deftly hands her a new one from his desk top, McCabe * taps on Remy's office door and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCABE: He. wasn't at the barber shop, so * we had to go pick him up at his house.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Bring. him in. Remy rises as Vincent "The Cannon™ Di Moti enters. A once young and vigorous capo unwilling to admit he's old--his hair is. dyed, his cheeks are rouged; he wears a dark pin-striped suit: his cane is in the shape: of a golf club. * REMY. . Thank you. for coming in, Mr. Di Moti. This is Miss Osborne with the District Attorney's office. The Cannon lowers himself onto a chair, leaning on his * cane.. a THE CANNON oN My lawyer is gonna get me out of ( ) here in five minutes. I. got

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: nothing to say til then.”

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (shocked) Why, you're not under arrest Mr. Di Moti. Did McCabe here give you that impression? Apologize to Mr. Di Meti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McCABE (plays along) : I'm sorry for the misunderstanding, Mr. Di Moti.:.

dialogues.speaker: REMY. . '
dialogues.text: You're free to go anytime. Mr. Di Moti. We apologize. The Cannon rises with difficulty, starts for the | door. *

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: We only wanted to express our sympathy about. Freddie. The Cannon stops at the door, turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . Who?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: You: know, Freddie Angelo, the guy they found floating in the fountain last night behind your office.

dialogues.speaker: THE. CANNON
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. He used. to work. for me. Terrible thing. Nobody has any respect for monuments anymore. . He turns to leave again. Anne suddenly jumps. in.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Isn't it true that. Mr. Angelo . * worked for you for twenty years and that. he was, in fact in your employ at the time of his death? The Cannon looks at. Remy as if to say “who the hell is this?” Remy shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy nods. followed by

dialogues.speaker: THE CANNON
dialogues.text: You know, kid, your father would never have dragged me down here like this. He knew a little something about respect. Can I go now? The Cannon strides out of the office, McCabe. Anne turns to Remy, steaming. ANNE. I. can't believe you were so obsequious with that man.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: What does obsequious mean?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: It means you had a high ranking member of the Mafia in your : office and you kissed his

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: ass. Well, first of all, nobody uses word, "mafia" anymore. Down here, we call ‘em "wise gays”. mention this to save you embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I'll bear that in mind... Anything elise?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I only Actually, I learned a lot. from that little interview.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Ooh yeah? You. read Tarot cards?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (laughs) I read people. For instance, after seeing The Cannon, can probably tell you why Freddie sprung a leak last night.

dialogues.speaker: I
dialogues.text: Hey, you like spicy food? Why don't we have dinner tonight? a place... I know 10.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Just tell me what you found out from two minutes of ass- kissing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Remy is beginning to realize that Ms. Osborne is quite capable of holding her own.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Freddie Angelo was one of the Cannon's. top men, see? Killing him and dumping him in the Piazza d'Itaila--that was a message to Vinnie. i ANNE And the message was...?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I think somebody's telling him it's time to retire. Last time I saw him he didn't have a hearing aid or a cane, either. He's " gotton old. Some of his people may be getting restless.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: This all sounds pretty flimsy to me. REMY. There's. more. Normally, he goes to his barber every morning for a shave and a manicure. Today, he. stayed home.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Meaning what?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Meaning the message is coming through loud and clear.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I. suppose you. know who the killer is, too?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: No, but in a week or so, I bet “we: find his. body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: il.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Then what. will you do?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Nothing. We'll never get ) anything we can take to court. Hell, I'd close the case right now except for one thing. .

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: What's that? ~

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I'll tell you over dinner. : ANNE . ’ : I'm here in an official capacity * Lieutenant...

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (charming smile) Come on, everbody has to eat, even cops and A.D.A.'s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . ... . -Anne smiles as. well ° Cut. to: . 18: EXT. K-PAUL's. - NIGHT ~ 18 Remy's LeBaron pulls up to a fire hydrant in front of this funky, but world-famous restaurant. Remy flips down his sun visor so that it shows an official placard: "police Business." Anne notes this, disapprovingly. There is a line of people half a block long waiting outside the door which is guarded by a uniformed cop, MAURICE. He opens the door as Remy and Anne approach. The crowd whistles as. they are ushered inside. ANNE. This is embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Nah, this is what's great about being a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The joint is jammed and jumping, crowded with people tables packed around a small dance floor where Little Queenie and the Radiators crank out the quintessential New. Orleans “Second Line" backbeat. The din is so loud you have to shout to be heard. The bar is absolutely packed, people standing three deep. Perched on a stool strategically placed between the cash register and the kitchen door sits the gargantuan black-bearded Patron, CHEF PAUL, taking little taste from the overflowing plates the waiter carry out. He waves. to Remy holding up five fingers.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (to Anne) : It'll be five minutes... Anne looks around agog at all this activity. The music is infectious, starting her foot to tapping. Remy notices.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Dance: with me...We'll work up an appetite.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I thought. we were here to discuss. business?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Not at the bar...Never know. who Might be listening... Anne smiles as Remy leads her out onto a dance floor filled with bouncing, sweaty people. Anne is a little intimidated, having a hard time picking up the idiosyncratic: beat.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Didn't they dance where you come from?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: They didn't dance at all. Remy leads her. into it, showing her the steps. 19

dialogues.speaker: , REMY
dialogues.text: Well, this is New Orleans, Cher. Down here, dancing is a way of life. Anne does her best to pick up the beat as we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dancing is over, the room has cleared out a bit. Anne and Remy are seated at a table in the back, picking over. the remains of a sumptous meal crawfish etouffee, file' gumbo, blackened redfish. Anne is a little bit. disheveled tipsy, sweating and flushed from the spicy food, laughing at Remy's put-on Cajan accent. ‘ REMY My people on my Mana's side, dey was the real Cajun, borned and deaded on the Bayou Teche. I used to pass myself down there in the summer wid my uncle Vern. A Cajun, he gets a little money in . his. pocket, he quits his job and spend it all--jaissuz les bons temps. rouler--let de good times roll. ANNE. I thought you came from a family - of Irish cops.

dialogues.speaker: REMY.
dialogues.text: That's on my Daddy's side. He was the first one to become a cop...

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (Finishing his sentence) «..followed by three brothers, a son, and four nephews... REMY. (interrups) Cousin Terry joined the Fire Department. Black sheep of the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: is.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Your father was killed in the line of duty...You're the youngest detective to ever make lieutenant...

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I had an- in in the department * ANNE. (smiles) Careful who you tell that. to... *

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Oh, I forgot...You bust * cops for a living...

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I'm not embarrassed to put bad cops behind bars. Remy pours out the last of the wine, changes the subject. . Tell. me something: about your * life. ANNE. It"s not as. colorful as yours.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: How do. you know all this. stuff * about. me?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I: investigate cops, remember? Got a file on you this thick. * It even has a picture of you as. an altar boy. You were very cute in. your little outfit.

dialogues.speaker: REMY,
dialogues.text: Is: that the juiciest thing you. could find?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: You were married, briefly...

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Very briefly.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: You've had a series of love affairs since then, but nothing all that serious. _~ Remy leans toward her with a twinkle in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: To me they were all serious... (taking Anne's hand) Would. you like me to tell you why I'm not closing the Angelo case.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (self-conscious about Remy touching her) . That's supposed to be why I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: It's you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (skeptically) Oh, please... Suddenly’ Remy is very much a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come an assistant. District Attorney on the Official Corruption Strike Force is suddenly interested in a routine Mafia hit? ANNE’ (easing her hand away) "Wise guy". A routine wise guy hit.

dialogues.speaker: . REMY
dialogues.text: What. gives? ANNE. (business-like) Our office has jurisdiction to investigate any crime we see fit.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Is there some police corruption angle on this case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for the first time Anne realizes that she's underestimated Remy.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: No comment.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Do you have any evidence at ali? Another beat. Anne doesn't answer. Suddenly, Chef Paul appears at tableside.

dialogues.speaker: CHEF PAUL
dialogues.text: How's everything? You like that gumbo? (to Anne) Remy's great-aunt. Emmeline taught me my gumbo. (xidding) . I don't know, Paul, Emmeline uses a lot more of dat sassafrass file’ in hers.

dialogues.speaker: CHEF PAUL
dialogues.text: Watch your month, boy! You won't. get no dessert. We got. Cajun coush-coush. We got special dobash. cake... Remy looks at Anne

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Nothing for me, thanks.. I've got. to be up early tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I guess just the check tonight.

dialogues.speaker: CHEF PAUL
dialogues.text: Waht you talking about, cher? REMY. I: want the check, Paul.

dialogues.speaker: CHEF PAUL
dialogues.text: (to Anne) Remy pass loss his mind!- He knows his money's no good in here. ANNE. Then give me the check.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (deadpan) Anne. here is with the District Attorney's office.

dialogues.speaker: CHEF PAUL
dialogues.text: Oh, really? {then he gets it) Hey, Remy, you. want your check? It's right here all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy's LeBaron turns a corner and finds the street blocked: by a group of TRANSVESTITES, staging an impromptu "Southern. Decadence" parade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A portable blue. police light sits. in the well between Anne's and Remy's seats, along with a two-way radio and a box of shotgun shells. Remy takes the light, puts in on the dashboard, flicks it on. The flashing blue light disperses the Transvestites. Remy steers the LeBaron through them. Anne looks disapprovingly at the array of police paraphernalia.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Does the police department outfit. all of the. detectives' private cars like this?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: It's a "spook car”... confiscated in a drug bust... makes for good cover. ANNE. Nice job--free car, free food... You: honestly don't see the harm in any of this? REMY . Neo, I don't see the harm... these: are. the perks. 18. 21 22

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: But the restaurant is going to expect extra protection in return, and expect the officer. to overlook any code violations.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: If all the codes were enforced you wouldn't have a restaurant in this city that could stay open.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: So what you're deaing here is defending corruption.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I'm not defending anything. This is. New Orleans, darling. Folks have a certain way of doing things down here. People like to show their gratitude. Anne snorts, offended by his smugness. ANNE. So how does it work? You get free suits? An envelope from Chef Paul every week? Remy pulls up to a red light, gives her an amused, incredulous look. He plucks. open the lapel of her blouse, looks down. ue

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: You got a wire in there? She: smacks his hand away. Remy looks down the street, then drives straight through the red light. Anne rolls. her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious, you know. How far does this stuff to? Is everything for. sale? What does it cost to beat a murder rap?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (genuinely insulted) Is that what you think about * cops? You got a real bad attitude, lady... ANNE. This evening hasn't done much to * improve it any. I've never see one person break so may laws in so ' short.a space of time.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Forget about the law for just a * minute. When you get out on the ' street it's very simple--there are the good guys and the bad guys... ANNE. And you're the Good Guys? _. REMY . Damn: right.. And we're all that stands. between. you. and them..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne gets out of the car. Then turns back for a parting shot. .

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Don't think that I'm naive. I know the way the system works. But things can change. . ’ REMY Yeah? You gonna change ‘em? She: turns, starts away. Remy hops out. of the car.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Is this your building?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: No, I live up the street. I just want to. get a few things.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I'll wait and drive you the rest of the way.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I'd rather walk.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I'll walk with you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Thank you for a very illuminating evening. Remy watches as she turnes and enters the White Hen Pantry.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 23
dialogues.text: EXT. ANNE'S STREET - NIGHT - LITTLE LATER © . 24 Anne is walking up her street burdened by two plastic shopping bags in addition to her briefcase. Suddenly, behind her, a woman .SCREAMS:

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN., (O.S.)
dialogues.text: My purse! Anne turns. around to see a MUGGER running toward her, clutching a woman's purse. Instinctively Anne swings one of her shopping bags at the mugger's legs, and the mugger takes a nosedive into the pavement. But Anne doesn't see... {THE SECOND MEGGER who plows: into her, and she smashes into the pavement with a sickening crunch. The wind's -been. knocked out of her but still she grabs the Second Mugger's ankle. He tries: to twist away but... ANNE won't let go even though. he's dragging her along the pavement, trying to kick his foot out of her grip. But. now the... FIRST MUGGER has gotten up and has pulled a knife on Anne, either to threaten her or to stick her, but just then...
REMY'S LEBARON bounces up onto the sidewalk, knocks the First Mugger flying. In a flash, Remy's out of the car, gun down and shouting.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Police: The Second Mugger tries to dodge past and Remy slams him on the side of the head with the pistol and he sinks to his knees. Remy levels his gun right at the First Mugger's face no more than four feet away.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Don't screw up! The First Mugger drops the knife. Anne-- dazed-- starts to get up, but Remy stops her.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (Continuing) Stay down for a second. (to Pirst. Mugger) Get down flat on your face. Right. there. That's right. (to Second Mugger) You, too, face down on the sidewalk there.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND MUGGER
dialogues.text: Me?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: No, the Pope! Face down. Very cautiously Remy frisks his prisoners, one at a time, his gun covering them closely. He flings the contents of their pockets out into the gutter. CAMMERA MOVES IN tighter and tighter on Anne, as she listens, her face registering, first shock, then disbelief, then anger, shame, humiliation.

dialogues.text: A TV monitor fills the frame. On it is a videotape of Remy taking the envelope. We PULL BACK to discover Anne, flanked by Hugh Dowling, the Internal Affairs cops, and three young LAWYERS. Anne's face is pale, over- controlled, she struggles not to show the disappointment, bitterness, betrayal she feels. The FIRST YOUNG LAWYER is a venal, cocky little guy.

dialogues.text: T can't

dialogues.text: I. want to be honest with: you. This particular case was a setup, but I've been on the take in. small. ways. since practically the day I joined the force. ‘Bobby puts his arm around Remy's shoulder.

BOBBY (continued) I. know you give Mama the money for my tuition, and it sure as hell doesn't come out of your salary. I'm only glad I can finally thank you.

dialogues.speaker: REMY

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY
dialogues.text: Seriously? :

dialogues.speaker: _ REMY .
dialogues.text: I was nineteen years old and about as innocent. as your : average altar boy. But hell, ' you were all about it. I should have asked you.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY

dialogues.text: Mama...

dialogues.text: A. very unfortunate happenstance, Miss Osborne.

dialogues.text: We. don't think it was an accident. Given the circumstances, Your Honor, the State requests a postponement. * on his sofa.

dialogues.text: He accepted the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamar Parmentel cross-examines.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: You testified that you were twenty feet from the defendant behind some crates on a balcony, looking down at his actions, is that. correct?

dialogues.speaker: INTERNAL AFFAIRS COP
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: And at this distance, you were unable to hear the conversation. between this George Joel and the defendant, isn't that the case?

dialogues.speaker: . INTERNAL AFFAIRS COP
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: You testified that there were eight fifty dollar bills in the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: . INTERNAL AFFAIRS COP
dialogues.text: That's correct.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: But. you cannot produce that money in court.

dialogues.speaker: INTERNAL AFFAIRS COP
dialogues.text: Sir, the: defendant dropped the money in the center. of the crowded bar. It's pretty clear that the people in the bar took the money but we couldn't just search. everybody who. was: there.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: Move the answer be stricken.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE. NOLAND
dialogues.text: Sustained . (to the witness) The court isn't interested in what.is "pretty clear" to you. The fact is that you cannot. produce the money in court.

dialogues.speaker: INTERNAL AFFAIRS COP
dialogues.text: No, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: _ LAMAR PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: No further questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy sits impassively as Anne examines George Joel, - the sweating tavern owner. He's sweating here, too. ANNE. Did the defendant promise that he would cause the uniformed officers to cease their harrassment of you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE JOEL
dialogues.text: If I. pay him, he would.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: And what would have happened if you did not make this payment to the defendant?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE JOEL
dialogues.text: If I don't pay, the police close me down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ’ Remy's lawyer cross-examines.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR. PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: Have you ever been arrested?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Prosecution will stipulate * that the witness. is currently under indictment and reminds the: court that clergymen and bankers are seldom witnesses at criminal trials.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: Isn't it true that you would Say anything the prosecution wanted you to say in order to avoid being sent. back to prison?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE JOEL
dialogues.text: Yes. >

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Objection.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE. JOEL
dialogues.text: I mean, no! I got mixed up!

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Move this all will stricken.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE NOLAND
dialogues.text: Sustained. Strike question and answer... Both answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge bangs his gavel.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE NOLAND
dialogues.text: Court is adjourned until ten o'clock tomorrow morning. Anne, tight-lipped and serious, gets: up immediately and packs her briefcase. From the other counsel table Remy watches her snap the briefcase shut and leave. She: doesn't look at him or at anyone else. Remy watches her go. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A corrugated metal warehouse near the river. FIRE ALARMS are RINGING. Smoke pillows through windows and garage doors; the glow of a fire inside. We hear SIRENS approaching. A few passers-by are gathering. Suddenly, an EXPLOSION inside blows. out the front doors, knocking several. pedestrians off their feet. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RINGING PHONE wakes Remy out of a sound sleep.

dialogues.speaker: REMY,
dialogues.text: (to phone) It's. three in the goddam monring. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FPiretrucks, police cars and TV news crews are parked in front of the bombed out building; a crowd has gathered behind the police lines. Detective McCabe is talking to Remy from a phone booth. McCABE It's McCabe, Remy, sorry to bother you but somebody just blew up Carmone Tandino's warehouse--with him in it.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (off) Jesus Christ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah! There's another body here - no I.D., nobody knows him; maybe you. can make him.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (off) I'll be right down.

dialogues.speaker: MCCABE
dialogues.text: You better not come here, Remy, The Deputy Supe is here talking to the TV guys. Meet. us at the morgue in an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy is getting dressed as he talks with McCabe.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: It's a free country. I'll meet you at the scene in fifteen minutes. He hangs: up and immediately starts to dial another number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although it"s after three in the morning Anne - dressed in a terry cloth bathrobe- is wide awake and working at her dining room table, which is stacked with papers and documents:

dialogues.speaker: TABLE STREWN WITH DOCUMENTS
dialogues.text: Among the documents is Remy's file, and in the middle of it is a. photo of Remy as an angelic altar boy. Anne is drawing a pair of horns and a devil's tail onto Remy's picture. The phone RINGS. She grabs it on the first ring. .

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Anne Osborne.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (off) Carmine Tandino was just killed at his warehouse on the Third Street Wharf. I thought you'd want to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy's on foot, keeping in the shadows on the dark street. Reporters and TV camera are gathered around Captain Kellom. Remy slips behind the police barricades. A UNIFORMED COP starts him away, then recognizes him.

dialogues.speaker: UNIFORMED COP
dialogues.text: Hey, Lieutenant. - Remy silences him with a finger to his lips, slips inside

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The warehouse is filled with MARDI GRAS FLOATS, each carrying gigantic papier mache' FIGURES of greek gods, celebrities, naked women, etc. As Remy threads his way through this phantasmagorical tableau toward the still- smoking scene of the explosion, McCabe appears at his side, punckes him in the arm. .

dialogues.speaker: MCCABE
dialogues.text: Hey, Remy I told you. not to come.. REMY. I'm not here. Where are the stiffs?

dialogues.speaker: MCCABE
dialogues.text: This way. It looks to.me like this - the killer sets a fire to destroy the bodies, the fire hits. a gas: tank on one of the floats, the gas tank explodes - and the explosion blows out the fire.. Remy pats McCabe on the head.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: How did you identify Tandino? McCabe smiles with relish, opens her hand: a glass eye lies in her. paln.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Carmine Tandino's glass eye! Way to go, kid.

dialogues.speaker: MCCABE
dialogues.text: Come down here a minute. This is the second stiff - we don't know who he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leads him behind a charred float, where a partially burned body lies. face up on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: MCCABE
dialogues.text: It looks like this guy was hiding back here when they killed Tandino.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Shit, I know who it is. It's Tandino's older brother.

dialogues.speaker: MCCABE
dialogues.text: I didn't know he had a brother.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Not many people did. Poor. guy was retarded. Family kept him at. home, and he did some work. sweeping up the warehouse. Jesus Christ, they killed a poor retarded guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne enters at.a fast pace into the darkened warehouse. Captain Kellom is puffing to keep up with her.

dialogues.speaker: KELLOM
dialogues.text: This is where: they keep some of the floats for Mardi Gras. Look at. this. one over here. Ain't it beautiful? But Anne isn't interested. She's barrelling her way | toward the lit-up scene of the crime.

dialogues.speaker: THE CRIME SCENE
dialogues.text: The usual Photographers and. Forensic Technicians. are doing their work. Someone is crouched over the body, blocking it from our view. As he rises and turns, -we see that it's Remy. He grins.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (to Kellom, outraged) What is this man doing here?

dialogues.speaker: KELLOM
dialogues.text: (to McCabe) What: is this man doing here? Before McCabe can answer, Remy comes up to them.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: More to the point, what. are you doing here? KELLOM. Yes, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I got an anonymous phone call. She brushes past Remy to look at the body.

dialogues.speaker: SHOCK CUT
dialogues.text: All. charred and blackened. There is a gaping hole in the chest. :

dialogues.speaker: MCCABE
dialogues.text: (with glee) They ripped the heart. right. out of his chest. Anne starts to get dizzy. Remy catches her, tries. to put his arms around her. She angrily shoves him away. Pulls herself together. ANNE. (to McCabe) Why would they do a thing like that? MCCABE» Voodoo.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Daddy Mention.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Daddy Mention? The black heroin. kingpin?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (nods) And voodoo priest.

dialogues.speaker: . MCCABE
dialogues.text: Black magic. Gris-gris. That's Daddy Mention's thing.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: "The heart of your enemy makes you. strong”.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: So you're saying that Daddy Mention killed Carmine Tandino. (Remy nods) Supporting your theory that Tandino killed Daddy Mention's men inthe projects the other night? . .

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: So what we got a nice little _gang war going here.

dialogues.speaker: KELLOM
dialogues.text: (noticing Anne's skeptical look) Doesn't it satisfy you, Ms.. Osborne? . ° Not particularly. {to Remy) I"ll. see you in court tomorrow, Mr. McSwain. * She turns on her heel and stalks off. Remy throws an arm. over Kellom's shoulder. McCabe punches Remy in the arn. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spectators, almost all Remy's family, watch as Anne cross~examines Remy on the witness stand. Mama, prominent in the front row, is sitting on the edge of her seat, her face registering ever emotional shift as the drama unfold

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: You have testified that you went to. the tavern to see an informer.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Yes ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: If it is true that you. were engaged in your duties asa policeman, why did you run away from the Internal Affairs Officer?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: He did not. identify himself asa cop. TI thought he was a. mugger.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Were you armed?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Yes. ANNE. And you ran away from a mugger?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I was trying to call for assistance, which is proper police procedure. Mama nods with approval, nudges Aunt Emmeline beside her. ANNE. They why did you chew up and swallow the envelope?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: That's ridiculous, I did no such thing..

dialogues.speaker: ANNY
dialogues.text: Then where is the envelope? “REMY What. envelope?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: The envelope that George Joel gave to. you. The envelope that contained eight fifty- dollar bills -- LAMAR PARMENTEL. (interrupting) Objection, Your Honor! Counsel is. drawing conclusions --

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE NOLAND
dialogues.text: Sustained. '

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (continuing) eothe eight. fifty-dollar bills that you threw into the air! The envelope that you ate! Mama clutches her heart, stung by the vehemence of Anne's anger.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: Objection!

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE NOLAND
dialogues.text: Sustained! . * Anne suddenly shuts up. A murmur goes through the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE,
dialogues.text: No further questions, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. McSwain. You may step down. Remy steps down and returns to his seat, never taking his eyes. off Anne. She won't look at him. But finally, she does. Mama, sees. this.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: Your Honor, the defense at this time moves for dismissal. The spectators become silent; they know this is the key moment.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: May I be heard on the motion, Your Honor?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE NOLAND
dialogues.text: Miss Osborne.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Your Honor, the State has shown that the defendant was present at. the place and time the crime was committed and has presented ; testimony by police officers linking the defendant to the exime, in addition to eyewitness testimony. .

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: By a convicted felon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sos The credibility of the witness is. not at. issue in a preliminary hearing -- that is for a jury to decide.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: May I be heard, Your Honor?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE NOLAND
dialogues.text: Mr. Parmentel.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: . The State has failed to establish * any crime at all. All that's been proven is that the defendant was present in the Toulouse Bar & Grill which was open for business at. the time.

dialogues.speaker: . JUDGE NOLAND
dialogues.text: It is the ruling of this court that there is no prima facie case: against the defendant. The charges are therefore dismissed. The defendant is ordered released and bail is vacated.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE NOLAND
dialogues.text: Court. is adjourned. The. family engulfs Remy, Uncles, Cousins, pumping his hand, pounding his back. Mama plants a big kiss on Lamar Parmentel's cheek. Remy watches Anne alone at the counsel table, packing her briefcase, disgusted. She squeezes through the crowd throws a sidelong glance at Remy as she goes. He's staring right at her. She turnes quickly away, hurrying out. Remy is whispering to UNCLE SAL. They are both watching the departing figure of Anne. Uncle Sal is nodding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is running. In well-worn sweat-clothes, on top of the high levee that separates the river from the eity. Running purges her demons. As she runs, all the anger and humiliation of the courtroom begin to disappear from her face. She glances over her shoulder, notices a police car, pacing her from behind on the road below. She keeps running in long, loping strides. Then looks back again.

dialogues.speaker: THE POLICE CAR 106
dialogues.text: Suddenly its flashing blue light goes cn, and the car veers off the road and accelerates up the grassy incline to the top of the levee. Anne stops, frightened. The police car pulls up beside her.. Uncle Sal steps out.

dialogues.speaker: . UNCLE SAL
dialogues.text: Miss. Osborne, would you. please come with me? ~

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: What? Where?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE SAL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, ma'am, I'm not at liberty to say. He takes her gently by the elbow, starts to lead her toward the car. ANNE. What's this supposed to be, * a joke?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE. SAL
dialogues.text: No. ma'am. .

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Am. I under arrest? *. Uncle Sal shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: What's the charge? *

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE SAL
dialogues.text: (looks around) Well, you jaywalked on the way over here.. you've been trespassing since you went through that hole in the fence...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She yanks her elbow from his grasp.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE. SAL
dialogues.text: (continuing) And. that could be construed as resisting arrest. Ann glowers at him. ANNE. Haven't I seen you before?.. Is your name, by any chance, McSwain? Uncle Sal smiles, nods, guides her into the car.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (burning) - I should: have known.

dialogues.speaker: ON A "CAJUN SQUEEZE-BOX", (FRENCH ACCORDION)
dialogues.text: playing, CAMERA PULLING BACK to reveal an impromtu family band on the porch -- squeeze box, fiddle, washboard, triangle, and Remy on the guitar, singing backup harmony to Uncle Lafayette's redition of "Ma Negresse". People are. dancing on a big piece of linoleum spread out on the grass. Remy's brother, Bobby, is dancing with McCabe, who looks like a girl for the first time. Kellom is presiding over the barbeque, wearing a chef's toque, and a t-shirt . emblazoned with a flaming bottle of Tabasco sauce. Severa dogs: watch him expectantly. The song ends. Everybody cheers. Dodge hands Kellom a beer, and Kellom steps up onto the porch to make a speech.

dialogues.speaker: KELLOM
dialogues.text: Boy, these Cajuns know how to throw a party, don't they? : (cheers) ,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: aN

dialogues.speaker: OC
dialogues.text: we

° KELLOM (continued) Lemme get serious for a minute. Those of us on the force know that injustice is often a part . of a policeman!s_lot_in. life: long hours, short. pay, mortal danger and never a thanks. from the public which we serve. Yet there are moments like this one, _ where justice triumphs, and that makes it all worthwhile. So now, I invite you, ladies and gentlemen, to raise your cups along with me. I. give. you...the Police Department of the City of New Orleans!

dialogues.speaker: COUSIN NICK
dialogues.text: And the Fire Department!

dialogues.speaker: KELLOM
dialogues.text: That's right, the Fire Department, too! Everybody joins in the toast Kellom gives Remy a big bear hug. Remy'’s embarrassed, squirms out of his grasp. The band starts up again. A pair of headlights crosses the bride and parks on the road in front ot the house -- it's Uncle Sal's police car Remy starts across the lawn toward the car. Anne comes bursting out of the back seat and storms up to him.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE.
dialogues.text: So now you're adding kidnapping and false arrest. to the list of your crimes.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Why you're not under arrest. Did Uncle Sal here give you that impression? (to Uncle Sal) Apologize to the lady, Sal.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE. SAL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry for the misunderstanding, Miss. Osborne.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: And now you're going to tell me I'm free to go. REMY . Absolutely. You're free to go anytime you. want.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Where's the phone? REMY. (pointing) In the house. Come on, I'll show you.

dialogues.speaker: . ANNE
dialogues.text: I can find it myself. She brushes past him, suddenly finds herself facing a swarm of dancing, drinking cops and Cajuns. She takes a deep breath and starts through them toward the house. Familiar faces from the courtroom glance at her - - some benignly curious, others hostile.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: (off) What's she doing here? Remy starts to follow her, when he is sidetracked by his nepher, Justin, 7, tugging at his trousers. ©

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Hey,. Justin.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: The judge said you were innocent Uncle Remy. I. told everyone you would never do what they said you did..

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's what the judge said. * Remy sweeps the kid up onto his shoulders and dances him through the crowd. looking for Anne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is on the telephone. Her voice is raised, her - * frustration evident.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: How soon can you be here! * Suddenly, Mama comes bustling out of the kitchen carrying a huge bucket of crawfish.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: You. said some pretty strong things about my boy in the courtroom today.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Yes, I did.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: ‘He's a good boy.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE ,
dialogues.text: He could be a hell of a lot better.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA
dialogues.text: (a smile) Well, Cher...you got your work cut for you on that score... EXT. MAMA'S YARD. - SAME : ill Remy, playing in the band, watches Anne emerge from the house. Mama follows her, and carries the bucket of crawfish to a big lawn table, where she dumps it into a bright red mound. Anne watches from a few yards off as people gather around and dig in. Captain Kellom and DeSoto are eating voraciously, their mouths and hands dripping with sauce. Kellom spots Anne and he and De: Soto carry a serving of crawfish over to her.

dialogues.speaker: KELLOM
dialogues.text: Never eat crawfish before? Here, . look, you bust off the tail like ‘this...then you pinch the shell 'till it cracks, peel it open and take out the meat... (he: demonstrates smacking his lips) good eatin’. Anne looks on, a small smile creasing her face. *

dialogues.speaker: KELLOM
dialogues.text: (continuing) If you're Cajun, you suck the head. I'm Irish, so I give it to DeSoto. DeSoto and Kellom laugh as DeSoto sucks the crawfish's head.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE PORCH
dialogues.text: Remy, playing with the band, looks across the crowd toward Anne. He steps to the front of the porch and sings: to her... . REMY . "You. used to call me in the morning. You used to call me late at night...Now you don't call. me anymore. Why, oh why; Why, tell. me why, why don't you call me anymore?" (to Uncle Lafayette) et toi... , * Uncle Lafayette takes a solo on the squeeze box. Remy puts down his guitar, steps off the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy approaches Anne.

dialogues.speaker: REMY .
dialogues.text: Does: the lady care to dance?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: No..

dialogues.speaker: REMY .
dialogues.text: (taking Anne's arm) I eut.a hell of a rug, you know.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (glaring at Remy's hand * coldly) fake your hand off me.

dialogues.speaker: COUSIN NICK ,
dialogues.text: (suddenly) Come on, dance with the boy! Anne finds herself innundated with Remy's family and friends. Her cheeks burn as all call on her to dance with Remy, literally shoving the two together. Finally, against her will, and only under the joyful pressure from those assembled does she agree. The music strikes up once again. A cheer rises from the crowd, and Remy escorts Anne out to the makeshift dance floor. Remy is at his most charming. Anne glares. When the band finishes...
Satisfied?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Still mad at me, huh?

dialogues.speaker: / ANNE
dialogues.text: You. don't get it, do you. I hate everything you stand for...you're a cop...you're supposed. to uphold the law, but you make a mockery of it. You bend it...you twist it... and you sell it. I saw you take that bribe, resist arrest, tamper with evidence and perjure yourself under oath.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: And run a red light...don't forget that. ” ANNE. And. you. still think it is . funny. Face it, Remy, you're not. one of the Good Guys anymore. Anne turns and walks away. Remy watches her go. His face frozen. A taxi comes over the bridge and pulls up in front of the house. Anne trots toward it, and quick jumps in. Justin appears from behind a parked. car, staring at Remy, having heard it all. INT.. TAXI--NIGHT. ears are pouring down Anne's face, as the taxi speeds across the bridge over the Industrial Canal.

dialogues.speaker: EXT CANAL BRIDGE--SAME
dialogues.text: This canal connects the Mississippi to Lake Ponchartrain through a series of locks. The taxi ROARS over the metal bridge. CAMERA PANS DOWN: Two BLOATED BODIES float in the lock. curt TO: 113 114

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guerra and Duvivier are dividing up the stacks of greasy bills again. Remy's head pops in the door..

dialogues.speaker: . DUVIVIER
dialogues.text: Remy! Good to see. you back! .

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Say, listen boys. I want you to do me a favor.

dialogues.speaker: GUERRA
dialogues.text: Sure, Remy. Anything.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Take me off the pad.

dialogues.speaker: DUVIVIER
dialogues.text: What? .

dialogues.speaker: REMY -
dialogues.text: Take me off. the pad. Duvivier and Guerra look at. each other, dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: _GUERRA
dialogues.text: What: do you mean take you off the pad? REMY. I don't mean anything, just tos take me off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy hurries past the glassed-in security booth of the Property Room. There's a new YOUNG GUY behind the desk. He. waves eagerly to.Remy. Remy ignores him, keeps going. Kellom comes down the stairs, catches up to Remy, shoves some papers into his hand. :

dialogues.speaker: KELLOM
dialogues.text: Look at this! Remy looks at the papers, reacts, startled.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: What is this? Retirement papers? You? You. finally did. it?

dialogues.speaker: . KELLOM
dialogues.text: December thirty-first. you become the ranking officer in the Homicide Bureau. I'm dens & oe er ee 115 116

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I don't believe you.

dialogues.speaker: . KELLOM
dialogues.text: Your mother didn't believe me either. :

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: You asked her to marry you?

dialogues.speaker: KELLOM
dialogues.text: New Year's Day...and I'd be honored if you'd accept to be my best. man. Remy's speechless. He wraps Kellom in a hug.

dialogues.speaker: SIX TALL GLASSES
dialogues.text: hands reach in, dropping Alka-Seltzer, tomato juice, Worcestershire sauce, and, finally, a raw egg into each glass. Dodge and DeSoto are mixing hangover tonic for McCabe, Foster, and two others. McCabe, in particular, looks terrible. Remy enters, as the glasses are grabbed. DODGE. Welcome back, Remy! Everyone raises their glasses to toast him. REMY. All. right: all right, nobody ever died of a hangover! Remy hurries across the squad room. Dewey Piersall, former property clerk, is now ensconced at a corner desk, on the phone. He gives Remy the high sign as he passes. Remy ducks into his office, picks up the phone, dials.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Anne Osborne, please. Detective McSwain calling. ‘He sticks his head out into the squad room.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (continuing) McCabe, Dodge, DeSoto, Foster-- my office. Bring everything you've got. (continuing to phone) All right. Tell her I'll call back later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs into the fighting gets it. up the phone as the four detectives jostle tiny room, dumping files on Remy's desk, to get to the single empty chair. DeSoto They're like a football team grabassing in the locker room. Remy flips through the files.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (continuing) McCabe, what've you got that's new? McCABE (groans, hung over) Foster has. an interesting ° angle on the Freddie Angelo Murder. - {to Foster) You tell him.

dialogues.speaker: FOSTER
dialogues.text: Second Division fished two. floaters out of the canal last night. They turned out to be Mexican “deep sea fishermen..."

dialogues.speaker: DODGE
dialogues.text: ...suffering from an acute case of lead poisoning. DeSoto cracks up at. Dodge's feeble joke; offers around Maalox tabs.

dialogues.speaker: FOSTER
dialogues.text: They worked out of Veracruz. Long records of smuggling.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: What's this got to do with Freddie Angelo?

dialogues.speaker: FOSTER
dialogues.text: Turns out Mexican customs: had a wiretap on these two guys. Guys who the last call they got was from?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Freddie Angelo.

dialogues.speaker: FOSTER
dialogues.text: Right. And we know that Freddie Angelo went to Veracruz three days before he was killed.

dialogues.speaker: DESOTO
dialogues.text: Narcotics says Freddie never dealt personally with less than twenty, thirty keys.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Now,. that. could explain a gang way. One kilo of heroin always seemed. too small-time for eight people to get killed over. But twenty, thirty keys. makes. a lot more sense. So: where's the rest of it? Nobody answers.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (coninuing) Did anybody talk to Daddy Mention?

dialogues.speaker: DODGE
dialogues.text: (shrugs) What's. he gonna tell us? Where he's got it stashed?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (getting angry) It's not what he says, it's what you hear, asshole! You're supposed to be detectives, for Chrissake. Daddy Mention is the Number One suspect. in a string of murders you're supposed to be investigation, and you don't even go talk to the guy? McCABE Well, we all know. it's a gang war. Doddy Mention's trying to move in on Vinnie's actions.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: It's all very neat, but I don't buy it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: DESOTO
dialogues.text: Why not? Sounded great to me.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Anne: Osborne..

dialogues.speaker: DODGE
dialogues.text: What the hell does she know about it?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I don't know what she knows. But she. knows something. Which is more than you can say for yourselves. You haven't done shit since I've been gone.

dialogues.speaker: DODGE
dialogues.text: They're doing our jcbs for us.

dialogues.speaker: DESOTO
dialogues.text: One creep kills another creep, that's.one less creep we have to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: POSTER
dialogues.text: Why not let ‘em wipe each other out?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Because we're The Police. That's why not. The Good Guys, remember? I'm going to talk to Daddy Mention. He stalks out. CuT TO: EXT. BASIN STREET--DAY © 118 Anne is walking along the street bordering St. Louis No. 1 Cemetery, with Lamar Parmentel, her former courtroom rival. The cemetery is a city of above- ground tombs. We hear, in the distance, the sound of a approaching BRASS BANK playing a very fast ’ yendition of Professor Longhair's "Goin' to Mardi Gras.

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: “You really should become a defense lawyer, my dear. You meet. a much more colorful class of people. You're going to love Daddy Mention. He's a doctor of root, fruits, and snoots.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Is. there anybody you'wouldn't represent?

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: Darlin', every man is entitled to the best. defense money can buy. They turn the corner to find their way blocked by a black HIGH SCHOOL MARCHING BAND rehearsing intricate synchronized steps in themiddle of the street. Lamar Parmentel. hurries Anne across the street, to Daddy Mentio's "Maison des Dieux"-- an old, two-story. wooden house, the bottom half of which is a "“gris-gris" shop. A bunch of BLACK KIDS play on the sidewalk, under the watchful eyes of two WOMEN knitting on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE. .
dialogues.text: Why does he want to see me

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: (knowingly) Actually, it was my idea. I thought you might. be interested in what he has to say about the rash of killings we've had of ate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a cluttered shop, crammed to the rafters with herbs, remedies, John the Conqueror roots, feathers, statuettes, potions, gris-gris, candles--voodoo paraphernalia. A beautiful mulatto woman greets Anne and Lamar Parmentel as they enter. Children play underfoot, as she elads them to the back of the store, through a beaded curtain, and into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy Mention, a protly, serene, middle-aged black man, greets them in extravagant splendor. . His long frizzy gray hair stands on end, as if 2,000 volts. of electricity are shooting through his body. Three more KIDS run, screaming, through the room. ANNE . (to Daddy Mention) Are they all yours?

dialogues.speaker: DADDY MENTION
dialogues.text: Twenty-one children. and. fourteen grandchildren. I got lost on one of the bible verses that. said "Be fruitful. and multiply.” I didn't read no further. (leoks her over) You're a very lovely lady. Mr. Parmentel tells me you're doing some wonderful work, rooting out corruption in the Police Department.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Let's get down to business, shall we?

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: She's not. a woman who stands On ceremony. :

dialogues.speaker: DADDY MENTION
dialogues.text: Fine, fine. I like a lady who's. serious about her work. Mr.. Parmentel tells me you've been looking into the murders of them Italian boys. ANNE. Freddie Angelo and Carmine fTandino. That's right. As well as Jamaal Washington, Michael and Darnell Nobilier, all of whom allegedly worked for you.

dialogues.speaker: DADDY. MENTION
dialogues.text: The police are putting out this story that there's a gang war going on. Do you believe that? .

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: What. do you. believe?

dialogues.speaker: . DADDY. MENTION
dialogues.text: It's not what I velieve, it's what I know. I know there ain't no gang war going on. My people didn't kill no Freddie Angelo or. no what's- his-name, Tandino and cut out his heart our.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: So, who did it?

dialogues.speaker: DADDY MENTION
dialogues.text: I don't know. - But they're killing my people, too.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Why haven't you told this to the police?

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: Daddy's. had some unfortunate experiences talking with the police. A small boy, RODNEY, pokes his head. through the beaded curtain.

dialogues.speaker: RODNEY
dialogues.text: Policeman to see you, Daddy. With a speed hard to imagine in a man of his size, Daddy Mention disappears from the room into the bowels of the house. Lamar Parmentel steps out through the beaded curtain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy is waiting impatiently in the shop. He laughs as ! he sees Lamar Parmentel step through the curtain. REMY. Lamar! Don't tell me you represent this sleazebag?

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: I only represent. sleazebags, my boy. Just then, Anne steps out of the anteroom.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I want to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I don't think he wants to talk. to you.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I. didn't know you two. were so. close.
FOUR SHOTGUN BLASTS resound from the back of the house; followed by SCREAMS of women and children. Drawing a snub-nosed pistol from each hip, Remy runs down the hall. REMY. (continuing): Stay here!

dialogues.speaker: LAMAR PARMENTEL
dialogues.text: Wouldn't have it any other way. Anne runs after Remy, through a tide of panicked WOMEN and CHILDREN, down a long hallway, through a brightly-lit, steamy kitchen, and out into the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lush, overgrown, Daddy Mention lies dead in the doorway of a small voodeo shrine. Nearby, a wounded, BLEATING goat. We hear the second line rhythms of the BRASS BAND (OFF), leaving the cemetery. Then, we hear the SQUEAL of tires from beyond the ten-foot-high wall. at the back of the yard. Anne runs up behind Remy. He sprints to the wall, leaps, catches the top, and vaults over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy comes over the top of the wall, drops to the ground. The alley is T shaped--he's in the top of the T.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A four-door brown Ford is speeding toward. him, up the leg of the T. Remy rolls to avoid the oncoming car. Brakes SQUEAL, the Ford swerves right along the top of the T, roars off. Remy scrambles to his feet, FIRING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne hears the shots. With surprising agility, she kicks off her high-heeled shoes, and scales the oak tree that grows by the wall. She clambers out onto a branch that overhangs the alley. 122 123 124 125

ANNE's POV--THE ALLEY. , 126 The brown Ford. SCREECHES to a halt, as a garbage truck comes lumbering up the narrow alley, blocking its escape. The Ford goes into reverse and peels backwards down the alley--right at Remy. REMY. FIRES two quick shots at the Ford that's about to run him down, then sprints toward the side of the alley. But the Ford turns, following-- an incredibly skillful move, as. the Ford is speeding in reverse--and Remy jumps. up the wall he just come over--dropping his gun. His fingers just catch the top of the wall.

dialogues.speaker: THE WALL
dialogues.text: Remy barely manages to haul his legs out of the way as the Ford zooms by under him, seraping the wall beneath him. REMY. drops to the ground. THE FORD. barrels backwards, now with a clear path to the mouth of the alley.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: wrenches a birdhouse from a branch of the tree.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: dives. for his. gun.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: hurls the birdhouse down upon the escaping Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The birdhouse SMASHES the front window. The car speeds. backwards toward the mouth of the alley, swerving left and right, banging and bouncing off the walls,

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: runs down the alley after the Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wounded Ford comes spinning out of the alley, scattering the Marching Bandmembers in every direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne drops down from the tree. Remy grabs her by the shoulders, shakes her.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: \ What's: the goddamn secret? No at , bullshit now Anne. What's this evidence you people have of police involvement in the Freddie Angelo killing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne is startled by his intensity but not shaken by it; she thinks for a second.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I gather you're: beginning to think that the cops were involved. REMY. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: That was an unmarked police car--a piece-of-shit four-door with no chrome. Besides, you know anybody that can. drive like that? The only way to learn those kind of moves is years of pursuit driving... Now, what do you know?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE.
dialogues.text: We have an eyewitness who saw two men in an unmarked police car-dump Freddie Angelo's body in the Piazza d'Italia.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: How did they know it was an unmarked police car?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: She saw the blue light and the radio on the seat.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Why did you withhold that information from the police?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Because the police are the suspects. Remy's face is a map of devastation, as this information sinks in.

dialogues.speaker: . REMY
dialogues.text: (to himself) There is. no gang war, is there. Remy looks around, coming out of his daze. Band members are picking themselves up. One or two people are. down and bleeding. The WAILING of Daddy Mention’s family pours over the wall. A police car pulls up on Basin Street; we hear other sirens approaching.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: So what are you going to do. about it? Remy rubs his eyes and forehead. The more he thinks about this, the more painful it is.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I don't know. The Police Department is my goddamn family.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: These people are killers, Remy. Remy looks at her intensely. He replaces his pistol in its holster. He's. shaken, thinking hard. Two more police cars pull up. Remy watches the boys in blue jumping out of their cars, guns drawn throwing their weight around--all murder suspects, for the first time. REMY. (almost a whisper) What. do you want me to do? Go undercover in my own precinct house...?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: I've got a better idea... Remy looks. at her curiously. A fourth police car pulls up near the mouth of the alley. A UNIFORMED COP recongizes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Hey, Lieutenant! Remy grabs Anne by the hand, drags her back down the alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne and Remy are already seated in the chambers when Judge Noland, the Judge at Remy's trial, bustles in. JUDGE. Ah, Miss Osborne, I'm sorry to keep you-- . (breaking off) Well, Lieutenant, I didn't expect to see you two together.

dialogues.speaker: REMY .
dialogues.text: You aren't half as surprised as I am, Judge.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: How can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: . ANNE
dialogues.text: We have a rather unusual request for a search warrant. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy's LeBaron pulls into the red zone in front of the station; Remy and Anne get out. Two uniformed police officers are waiting on the sidewalk’ for them. A police car pulls up behind Remy's LeBaron and another pair of uniformed policemen join Remy and Anne on the sidewalk. We recognize all four officers from the party at Remy's mother's house. Remy makes the introductions. REMY. TI don't think. you all met the other night. My uncle Sal, my: cousin. Joey,. my uncle Frank, my uncle Steve. They say hello. (coninuing) Thanks. for helping out.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE. SAL
dialogues.text: Sure thing, Remy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy leaves Uncle Sal and cousin Joey just inside the door.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Check everybody going in or out. I don't care who they are.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE SAL
dialogues.text: You got it. : The DESK SERGEANT is halfway out of his chair.

dialogues.speaker: DESK SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Hey, Remy, what's going on? But Remy is leading his other uncles into the station house. Anne walks up to the desk.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE _
dialogues.text: Are you the desk officer on duty?

dialogues.speaker: DESK SERGEANT
dialogues.text: What do I look. like-- The King of Mardi Gras?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Then this is for you. She hands him a document in a blue legal ¢ cover. He looks it over incredulously.

dialogues.speaker: DESK SERGEANT
dialogues.text: What the hell? Captain Kellom enters the station.

dialogues.speaker: DESK SERGEANT
dialogues.text: (continuing) Hey, Captain! Some broad's here. with a search warrant! curT TO: INT. THIRD DISTRICT POLICE. STATION--ROSTER ROOM-DAYi A crowd of unrely UNIFORMED COPS presses into the main squad room. Guerra and Duvivier. exchange nervouse glances.

dialogues.speaker: GUERRA
dialogues.text: Do you believe this shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ANGLE WIDENS to SHOW Remy addressing the troops. Anne stands beside him rather intimidated by the loud grumbling of the officers.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Then I. want you to give me your _ ticket books and radio call legs, your mileage logs, and your TC 14's. Covering the dates in question. ~

dialogues.speaker: GUERRA
dialogues.text: I was on the day shift all week!

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I. don't care--I want this from all shifts.

dialogues.speaker: DUVIVIER
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch! ; And other grumbles grow louder--but they are cut off ~ suddenly as the men notice Captain Kellom walking ‘through the room.

dialogues.speaker: KELLOM
dialogues.text: May I interrupt, Lieutenant?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Of course, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: KELLOM
dialogues.text: We have been served with a legitimate court order and even thought. we may not understand it, we have-to obey it. Now I want. you. men to remember that the lieutenant here is one of our own--he's no shoefly-- and. this investigation is for the good of the department. Not only that, Miss Osborne here is an assistant D.A. and I expect you to respect her like you would me. You better be. aware that any officer who does not. willingly, fully and cheerfully cooperate with this investigation is going to wish his father and mother had never met. Is that clear?) Any questions? :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evidently it's quite clear. There are no questions. ’ KELLOM Very well. (whispers to Remy) I wish you'd come to me with this Remy. There are ways to handle these things. He stalks off; there is a sigh of relief in his wake, but no more complaints.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: I know this is a pain in the ass, but if it makes you feel any better once we get through here we're going to do the whole thing again with the detectives upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge and DeSoto are about to leave the building, when Remy's Uncle Sal steps in front of them. : SAL. Serry boys. TI got orders to pat everbody down. They shrug, hold up thier hands. Sal kneels, patting Dodge's ankles and legs. DESOTO. I. tell ya, Sal, this lawyer is leading Remy around by his nose.

dialogues.speaker: DODGE
dialogues.text: Try his dick. Sal frisks the inside of Dodge's thighs.

dialogues.speaker: DODGE
dialogues.text: Ooh, Sal TI love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 101 Sal pushes him away, turns to DeSoto. DeSoto immediately pulls up his trouser leg, revealing a small pistol in an ankle holster, and a hunting ; knife strapped to his calf. : He starts pulling things out of pockets and hidden recesses of his: clothing; a small automatic, a tiny deringer, a sap, a switchblade knife. Sal laughs, looks the stuff over.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Not what I'm looking for. Get outta here. : cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: INT SQUAD ROOM--REMY'S OFFICE--DAY 135
dialogues.text: Remy and Anne are on opposite sides of Remy's desk, each interviewing an officer. McCabe, Poster, Dewey Piersall and several other detectives are lined up outside the door, waiting their turns. Their faces wear expressions that range from annoyance to outrage. As we move into the room,. we catch a snatch of Remy's conversation.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: That's. car seventeen?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE NAPOLION
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: . REMY
dialogues.text: What. is your sector? .. while across the. seks, Anne talks with another cop...

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Was. the car damaged?

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE SHEXNAYDRE
dialogues.text: It was: in the shop for two days.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: What. was the nature of the damage? ...and behind them, in boxes, are growing piles of evidence: record sheets, ticket books, repair orders and the like...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy, Anne, Cousin Joey, and the GARAGE DISPATCHER, wander through the cavernous space, looking for the unmarked police car that tried to run Remy down. He spots it in a dark corner, among a bunch of disused vehicles.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: There it is.

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCHER
dialogues.text: Uh-uh. Tose are all junkers. (scans his clipboard) That baby hasn't been outta here in three months. - Meanwhile, Anne has gone over to inspect the car more closely.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Look...you hit it! Remy and the Dispatcher join her. She points to the trunk. : INSERT - THE TRUNK “137 It has a bullet-hole in it.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (to Joey) I want. this car impounded and dusted for fingerprints. cuT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun has just set. . Anne and Remy come down the steps, laden with folders and manila envelopes, crammed. with documents, followed by Remy's four cop relatives. A dozen other cops watch, hostilely, as Remy and Anne shake hands with the relatives; drive off in the LeBaron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat. or work?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Work.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: My place or yours?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Yours. Remy looks at her, startled. . That way I can leave when I want to. | Remy grins, steps on the gas; runs a red light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy and Anne are eating "po' boys" (New Orleans hero sandwiches) while they work. Remy frowns at the file he's looking at. . REMY. Have you: come across any pages like this?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: As if they're Xeroxed. Yes, I meant to ask you...

dialogues.speaker: REMY -
dialogues.text: What's the date on yours? ANNE. October twenty-fourth.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Mine too.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Freddie Angelo night. She burrows back into her papers.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: It means that they've already covered up the records; we're not going to find anything here.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: We'll. go on looking just in case.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anne's chin is propped. up on her hand, eyes are drooping. Her pencil falls from her fingers, startling her awake. She looks over at Remy

dialogues.speaker: ON REMY
dialogues.text: He's working frantically, totally absorbed, shuffling papers, comparing files, jotting down little notes-- he seems to be on to something. Suddenly he stops, lets out a deep breath. He looks ill. Then he notices Anne watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do. you have something?

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: (startled) Huh? Why? ANNE. You look strange. REMY. Fried oysters at one o'clock in the morning. Why don't we just call it a night. She picks up the phone, starts to dial.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Who. you calling?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: A cab.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Why not’ stay here? (at her look) I'll sleep on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: Thanks, anyway... As Anne finishes dialing, Remy reaches over and ry disconnects the call.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: You'll. be coming back here first thing, anyway. No hanky-panky. I promise. The bed is yours if you want. it. :

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: No, thank you. I'd rather go home.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Come on, Anne. Are you gonna ! be pissed off at-me for the rest of your life?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: (with a smile) Maybe. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remy knocks. on the: bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: REMY
dialogues.text: Are you decent?

dialogues.speaker: ANNE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sort. of. Remy sticks his head in the door, sees

dialogues.speaker: ANNE
dialogues.text: She's in the bedroom, wearing an old policeman's shirt of Remy's, bent of the sink, her mouth ringed white with toothpaste.
